   function rmh_event(cat,act,label) {

function blogEvents()
{

	$(function () 
	{
		$('a').each(function () 
		{
			var anchor = this;
			
			// if the a link has a rel AND the rel contains a (
			if( $(this).attr("rel") &amp;&amp; $(this).attr("rel").indexOf('(') !== -1){		    
			    
			    
// remove non events
match = $(this).attr("rel").match(/(\([\s\S]*\))/m);
if (match != null) {
	blogEvents = match[1].replace(/\(/g,";rmh_event(");
} else {
	blogEvents = $(this).attr("rel").replace(/\(/g,";rmh_event(");
}

    					if ($(this).attr("onclick")) //Check to see if an onclick already exists
    					{
    						// onclick exists: append
    						var onclickValue = $(this).attr('onclick');
    						if (onclickValue.charAt(onclickValue.length-1) == ";"){
    							$(this).attr("onclick", onclickValue + blogEvents);
    						}
    						else
    						{
    						    // add our onclick       
    							$(anchor).attr("onclick", onclickValue + blogEvents);
    						}
    					}
    					else
    					{
    					    // no existing onclick, just add ours	
    						$(anchor).attr("onclick",blogEvents);
    					}

			}
		}); //end loop a href's
	}); // end function
} // end blogEvents()

( function($) {
    // we can now rely on $ within the safety of our "bodyguard" function
    $(document).ready( function() { 
    	blogEvents();
    } );
} ) ( jQuery );

    <div id="heroshot">

    <div class="container" id="pagecontent">
     <div class="row">
      <div class="elevencol">
       <div id="content">
        <div id="singlepost">
         <div class="post-5307 post type-post status-publish format-standard hentry category-content tag-duplicate-content" id="post-5307">
          <div class="postlistitem">
           <div class="listitemheader row">
            <div class="featurepostimg">
             <img alt="" class="avatar avatar-76 photo" height="76" src="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/f8d69258525dec38624a29eb3d570d8c?s=76&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.searchenginepeople.com%2Fwp-content%2Favatars%2F35.jpg&amp;r=g" srcset="http://0.gravatar.com/avatar/f8d69258525dec38624a29eb3d570d8c?s=152&amp;d=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.searchenginepeople.com%2Fwp-content%2Favatars%2F35.jpg&amp;r=g 2x" width="76"/>
            </div>
            <div class="postheader">
             <h1 class="listtitle">
              <a class="listtitle" href="http://www.searchenginepeople.com/blog/how-to-quote-without-getting-into-googles-duplicate-content-filter.html">
               How to Quote without Getting into Google's Duplicate Content Filter?
              </a>
             </h1>
             <author>
              by  Ann Smarty
             </author>
             <date>
              October 26th, 2009
             </date>
            </div>
           </div>
           <div class="postbody">
            <div class="dd_post_share">
             <div class="dd_buttons">
              <div class="dd_button">
               <a class="twitter-share-button" data-count="horizontal" data-text="How to Quote without Getting into Google's Duplicate Content Filter?" data-url="http://www.searchenginepeople.com/blog/how-to-quote-without-getting-into-googles-duplicate-content-filter.html" data-via="senginepeople" href="http://twitter.com/share">
               </a>
               <script src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" type="text/javascript">
               </script>
              </div>
              <div class="dd_button">
               <div class="dd-linkedin-ajax-load dd-linkedin-5307">
               </div>
               <script data-counter="right" data-url="http://www.searchenginepeople.com/blog/how-to-quote-without-getting-into-googles-duplicate-content-filter.html" type="IN/share">
               </script>
              </div>
              <div class="dd_button">
               <script src="//connect.facebook.net/en_US/all.js#xfbml=1">
               </script>
               <fb:like href="http://www.searchenginepeople.com/blog/how-to-quote-without-getting-into-googles-duplicate-content-filter.html" layout="button_count" send="false" show_faces="false" width="92">
               </fb:like>
              </div>
              <div class="dd_button">
               <div class="dd-google1-ajax-load dd-google1-5307">
               </div>
               <g:plusone href="http://www.searchenginepeople.com/blog/how-to-quote-without-getting-into-googles-duplicate-content-filter.html" size="medium">
               </g:plusone>
              </div>
              <div class="dd_button">
               <a class="buffer-add-button ext-link ext-icon-19" data-count="horizontal" data-text="How to Quote without Getting into Google's Duplicate Content Filter?" data-url="http://www.searchenginepeople.com/blog/how-to-quote-without-getting-into-googles-duplicate-content-filter.html" data-via="senginepeople" href="http://bufferapp.com/add" rel="external" target="_blank" title="">
               </a>
               <script src="http://static.bufferapp.com/js/button.js" type="text/javascript">
               </script>
              </div>
              <div class="dd_button">
               <a class="pin-it-button ext-link ext-icon-19" count-layout="horizontal" href="http://pinterest.com/pin/create/button/?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.searchenginepeople.com%2Fblog%2Fhow-to-quote-without-getting-into-googles-duplicate-content-filter.html&amp;description=How%20to%20Quote%20without%20Getting%20into%20Google%27s%20Duplicate%20Content%20Filter%3F&amp;media=" rel="external" target="_blank" title="">
               </a>
               <script src="http://assets.pinterest.com/js/pinit.js" type="text/javascript">
               </script>
              </div>
             </div>
             <div style="clear:both">
             </div>
            </div>
            <div style="clear:both">
            </div>
            <p>
             There's one question people keep asking me: how to quote other people without being affected by Google's duplicate content filter. Yes, the most widely-used way to cite is to put the abstract in  quotes and link back to the source. But is everything really that simple?
            </p>
            <p>
             There are no "official" Google rules as to citing. The only thing we know is that Google loves unique content and filters out duplicate entries. There are no set standards as to how many duplicate words or set of words should be found in two documents for them to be considered duplicates or partial duplicates.
            </p>
            <p>
             So the only thing we can do is to make educated guesses. And to make them really educated, let's take a look at official rules and known precedents:
            </p>
            <p align="center">
             <img alt="Quoting without getting into duplicate content filter" height="300" src="http://farm4.static.flickr.com/3422/3907319162_bdfe0d32b0.jpg" width="480"/>
            </p>
            <h2>
             According to the Law
            </h2>
            <p>
             <em>
              Can you copy someone else's creative work at all?
             </em>
             The short and simple answer is NO:
            </p>
            <ul>
             <li>
              You
              <em>
               cannot
              </em>
              copy someone else's article even if you link back;
             </li>
             <li>
              There is no definitive rule as to how much you are actually allowed to copy.
             </li>
            </ul>
            <p>
             There  one exception though:
             <a class="ext-link ext-icon-19" href="http://www.copyright.gov/help/faq/faq-fairuse.html" rel="external" target="_blank" title="">
              "Fair use"
             </a>
            </p>
            <blockquote>
             <p>
              <strong>
               How much of someone else's work can I use without getting permission?
              </strong>
             </p>
             <p>
              Under the
              <em>
               fair use
              </em>
              doctrine of the U.S. copyright statute,     it is permissible to use limited portions of a work including     quotes, for purposes such as commentary, criticism, news reporting,     and scholarly reports. There are no legal rules permitting the     use of a specific number of words, a certain number of musical     notes, or percentage of a work. Whether a particular use qualifies     as fair use depends on all the circumstances
             </p>
            </blockquote>
            <p>
             Here's the best way to demonstrate what Fair use it: try to honestly answer the following question (example by
             <a class="ext-link ext-icon-19" href="http://www.templetons.com/brad/copymyths.html" rel="external" target="_blank" title="">
              10 Big Myths about copyright explained
             </a>
             which is a great read by the way)
            </p>
            <p>
             Are you copying / quoting an  article from the
             <em>
              New York Times
             </em>
             because you need to
             <strong>
              criticize / comment on / illustrate / clarify its quality
             </strong>
             / its statements / its conclusions, etc, or because you (1)
             <strong>
              couldn't find time to write your own
             </strong>
             story, or (2)
             <strong>
              didn't want your  readers to have to register
             </strong>
             at the New York Times web site?
            </p>
            <p>
             The following clarifications also must be taken into account:
            </p>
            <ul>
             <li>
              You are not allowed to copy  more of the work than is  needed to make the commentary (see point (1) above);
             </li>
             <li>
              Your quote  should not harm the  commercial value of the work (see point (2) above).
             </li>
            </ul>
            <p>
             Here are
             <a class="ext-link ext-icon-19" href="http://www.copyright.gov/fls/fl102.html" rel="external" target="_blank" title="">
              a few examples
             </a>
             of Fair use as cited 1961 Report of the Register of Copyrights on the General Revision of the U.S. Copyright Law:
            </p>
            <blockquote>
             <p>
              quotation of excerpts in a review or criticism for
              <strong>
               purposes of  illustration or comment
              </strong>
              ; quotation of short passages in a scholarly or  technical work,
              <strong>
               for illustration or clarification
              </strong>
              of the authors  observations;
              <strong>
               use in a parody
              </strong>
              of some of the content of the work  parodied; summary of an address or article, with
              <strong>
               brief
              </strong>
              quotations, in a  news report; ....
             </p>
            </blockquote>
            <p>
             Here are more examples from
             <a class="ext-link ext-icon-19" href="http://fairuse.stanford.edu/Copyright_and_Fair_Use_Overview/chapter9/9-c.html" rel="external" target="_blank" title="">
              Stanford Copyright &amp; Fair Use
             </a>
             section (I found the one especially interesting that contains actual numbers):
            </p>
            <blockquote>
             <p>
              <strong>
               Fair use.
              </strong>
              A biographer of Richard Wright quoted from six unpublished letters and ten unpublished journal entries by Wright.
              <em>
               Important factors:
              </em>
              <em>
               <strong>
                No more than 1%
               </strong>
              </em>
              of Wright's unpublished letters were copied and the purpose was informational.
             </p>
            </blockquote>
            <h2>
             Actual Web Practice
            </h2>
            <p>
             More often than not,  the rules across the web are quite fuzzy. You are just not allowed to copy "large" abstracts and you are required to link back to the source. However there are a few cases where requirements are more or less precise.
            </p>
            <p>
             For example, user generated news reporting site
             <a class="ext-link ext-icon-19" href="http://nowpublic.com/" rel="external" target="_blank" title="">
              NowPublic
             </a>
             doesn't allow to quote abstracts larger than 1000 characters
             <em>
              (it is not actually clear to me what this number is based on
             </em>
             ).
            </p>
            <blockquote>
             <p>
              <strong>
               Highlight:
              </strong>
              When you find a passage of text that youd like to share (up to 1,000 characters)...
             </p>
            </blockquote>
            <p>
             Also, there was a well-discussed copyright scandal in the past which must be mentioned here as tightly relevant: Associated Press
             <a class="ext-link ext-icon-19" href="http://www.webmasterworld.com/content_copywriting/3674148.htm" rel="external" target="_blank" title="">
              went after
             </a>
             webmasters for publishing its article titles and brief excerpts, claiming "Fair Use" does not permit this practice. As explained by Jim Kennedy, a vice-president and director of strategy for Associated Press,
            </p>
            <blockquote>
             <p>
              <em>
               We get concerned,  however, when we feel the use is more reproduction than reference, or  when others are encouraged to cut and paste.
              </em>
              That's not good for  original content creators; nor is it consistent with the link-based  culture of the Internet that bloggers have cultivated so well.
             </p>
            </blockquote>
            <h2>
             The Conclusions:
            </h2>
            <ul>
             <li>
              Quoting large abstracts can be bad fashion (make it no more than a couple of sentences);
             </li>
             <li>
              Quoting just because you can't find better words for saying the same thing is bad. Quote only when the quote makes sense: you need to comment on it.
             </li>
            </ul>
            <p>

             </em>
